<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and<BR>Results of Operations</FONT></P></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">18</FONT></TD></TR>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on<BR>Financial Statement Schedule</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">S-1</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Valuation and Qualifying Accounts</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">S-2</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In this report, &#147;Kraft,&#148; &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us&#148; and &#147;our&#148; refers to Kraft Foods Inc.
and subsidiaries, and &#147;Common Stock&#148; refers to Kraft&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">i </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>PART&nbsp;I </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Business. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>General </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft was incorporated in 2000 in the Commonwealth of Virginia. We manufacture and market packaged food products, including snacks, beverages, cheese, convenient meals
and various packaged grocery products. We have operations in more than 70 countries and sell our products in approximately 150 countries. We have nine brands with revenues exceeding $1 billion: <I>Kraft</I> cheeses, dinners and dressings; <I>Oscar
Mayer</I> meats; <I>Philadelphia</I> cream cheese; <I>Maxwell House </I>and <I>Jacobs </I>coffee; <I>Nabisco</I> cookies and crackers and its <I>Oreo </I>cookie brand; <I>Milka</I> chocolates; and <I>LU</I> biscuits. We have more than 50 brands with
revenues of at least $100 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Prior to June&nbsp;13, 2001, Kraft was a wholly owned subsidiary of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. (&#147;Altria&#148;). On
June&nbsp;13, 2001, we completed an initial public offering of 280,000,000 shares of our Common Stock at a price of $31.00 per share. In the first quarter of 2007, Altria spun off its remaining interest (89.0%)&nbsp;in Kraft on a pro rata basis to
Altria stockholders in a tax-free transaction. Effective as of the close of business on March&nbsp;30, 2007, all Kraft shares owned by Altria were distributed to Altria&#146;s stockholders, and our separation from Altria was completed. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Because Kraft Foods Inc. is a holding company, our principal source of funds is from our subsidiaries. Our wholly owned subsidiaries currently are not limited by
long-term debt or other agreements in their ability to pay cash dividends or make other distributions with respect to their common stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Reportable
Segments </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We manage and report operating results through two commercial units, Kraft North America and Kraft International. Kraft North America
operates in the U.S. and Canada, and we manage Kraft North America&#146;s operations by product category. We manage Kraft International&#146;s operations by geographic location. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective August&nbsp;4, 2008, we completed the split-off of the <I>Post</I> cereals business. The results of the <I>Post</I> cereals business were reflected as discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of
earnings and prior period results were restated in a consistent manner. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2008, we implemented a new operating structure. Within the new structure,
business units now have full P&amp;L accountability and are staffed accordingly. This also ensures that we are putting our resources closer to where we make decisions that affect our consumers and customers. Our corporate and shared service
functions continue to streamline their organizations and focus on core activities that can more efficiently support the goals of the business units. As a result of implementing the new operating structure, we began reporting the results of
operations under this new structure in the first quarter of 2008 and restated results from prior periods in a consistent manner. The changes were: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">U.S. Cheese was organized as a standalone operating segment in order to create a more self-contained and integrated business unit in support of faster growth.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our macaroni&nbsp;and cheese category, as well as other dinner products, were moved from our U.S. Convenient Meals segment to our U.S. Grocery segment to take
advantage of operating synergies. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Canada and North America Foodservice were structured as a standalone reportable segment. This change allows us to deliver on the unique requirements of the Canadian
consumer and customer while maintaining strong North American linkages to innovation, new product development and new capabilities to drive our business. Furthermore, it allows us to manage strategic customer decisions and continue to capture
cross-border sales and marketing synergies within our Foodservice operations. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Note 17, <I>Segment Reporting</I>, to our consolidated
financial statements includes a breakout of net revenues, segment operating income, total assets, depreciation expense and capital expenditures by reportable segment, as well as a breakout of net revenues, long-lived assets and total assets by
geographic region. Management uses segment operating income to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Management believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze segment performance and trends. Segment
operating income excludes unrealized gains and losses on hedging activities (which is a component of cost of sales), general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">1 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The relative percentages of total segment operating income attributable to each reportable segment were: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>

<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" COLSPAN="5" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>For&nbsp;the&nbsp;Years&nbsp;Ended&nbsp;December&nbsp;31,</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2008&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2007&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2006&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</B></FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" COLSPAN="15"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our brands span five consumer sectors:</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD HEIGHT="16" COLSPAN="13"></TD>

<TD HEIGHT="16" COLSPAN="2"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" COLSPAN="13"> <P STYLE="margin-left:4.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>Snacks</B> &#150; primarily biscuits (cookies and crackers), salted snacks and chocolate
confectionery;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top" COLSPAN="13"> <P STYLE="margin-left:4.00em; text-indent:-1.50em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<B>Beverages</B> &#150; primarily coffee, packaged juice drinks and powdered
beverages;</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>

and</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>

and processed meats.</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our U.S. subsidiaries export coffee products, refreshment beverage products, grocery products, cheese, biscuits
and processed meats. In 2008, these exports from the U.S. amounted to $195&nbsp;million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">2 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

December&nbsp;31, were: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="92%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Grocery:</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Royal</I> dry packaged desserts; <I>Kraft</I> spoonable and pourable salad dressings; <I>Miracle Whip </I>spoonable dressings; <I>Jell-O</I> dessert toppings; <I>Kraft</I> peanut butter;
and <I>Vegemite</I> yeast spread.</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Convenient Meals:</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Kraft</I> macaroni&nbsp;and cheese dinners.</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Effective January 2009, we began implementing changes built on our Kraft Europe Reorganization and our
<I>Organizing For Growth </I>initiative. In line with our strategies, we are evolving how we work in Europe in two key ways: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are transitioning our European Biscuit, Chocolate, Coffee and Cheese categories to fully integrated business units, further strengthening our focus on these core
categories. To ensure decisions are made faster and closer to customers and consumers, each category will be fully accountable for the P&amp;L, including marketing, manufacturing and R&amp;D. Category leadership, based in Zurich, will report to the
Kraft Europe President, and the country organizations will be aligned with the category structure under our Kraft Europe Reorganization and report directly to category management. Going forward, these business units will comprise the Kraft Foods
Europe segment. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are aligning the reporting of our Central Europe operations into our Kraft Foods Developing Markets segment to help build critical scale in these countries. We
intend to operate a country-led model in these markets and, as a result, we have no plans to implement the Kraft Europe Reorganization in Central Europe. This change also will keep Kraft Foods Europe management fully focused on implementing their
new structure and growing the business. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a result of implementing this new operating structure, we will report the results of
operations under this new structure beginning in the first quarter of 2009 and will restate results from prior periods in a consistent manner. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Significant Acquisitions and Divestitures </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>LU Biscuit Acquisition: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;30, 2007, we acquired the global <I>LU </I>biscuit business of Groupe Danone S.A. (&#147;<I>LU</I> Biscuit&#148;) for &#128;5.1&nbsp;billion (approximately $7.6 billion) in cash. The acquisition
included 32 manufacturing facilities and approximately 14,000 employees. We acquired net assets consisting primarily of goodwill of $4,052&nbsp;million (which will not be deductible for statutory tax purposes), intangible assets of
$3,546&nbsp;million (substantially all of which are indefinite-lived), receivables of $757&nbsp;million, property, plant and equipment of $1,054&nbsp;million and inventories of $204 million, and assumed liabilities of $1,063 million consisting
primarily of accounts payable and accruals. These purchase price allocations were based upon appraisals that were </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">4 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">finalized in the third quarter of 2008. <I>LU</I> Biscuit contributed net revenues of $3.2 billion during 2008, and $2.8 billion on a proforma basis during
2007. <I>LU</I> Biscuit reported results from operations on a one month lag in 2007; as such, there was no impact on our operating results. On a proforma basis, <I>LU </I>Biscuit&#146;s net earnings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 would
have been insignificant to Kraft. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Post Cereals Split-off: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;4, 2008, we completed the split-off of the <I>Post</I> cereals business into Ralcorp Holdings, Inc. (&#147;Ralcorp&#148;), after an exchange with our shareholders. The exchange is expected to be tax-free to participating
shareholders for U.S. federal income tax purposes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In this split-off transaction, approximately 46.1&nbsp;million shares of Kraft Common Stock were
tendered for $1,644 million. Our shareholders had the option to exchange some or all of their shares of Kraft Common Stock and receive shares of common stock of Cable Holdco, Inc. (&#147;Cable Holdco&#148;). Cable Holdco was our wholly owned
subsidiary that owned certain assets and liabilities of the <I>Post</I> cereals business. In exchange for the contribution of the <I>Post</I> cereals business, Cable Holdco issued approximately $665 million in debt securities, issued shares of its
common stock and assumed a $300 million credit facility. Following the merger of Cable Holdco and a Ralcorp subsidiary, the Cable Holdco common stock was exchanged for shares of Ralcorp common stock on a one-for-one basis. Upon closing, we used the
cash equivalent net proceeds, approximately $960 million, to repay debt. As a result of the split-off, we recorded a gain on discontinued operations of $937 million, or $0.62 per diluted share, in 2008. The results of the <I>Post</I> cereals
business were reflected as discontinued operations on the consolidated statement of earnings and prior period results were restated in a consistent manner. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">See Note 2, <I>Acquisitions and Divestitures</I>, to our consolidated financial statements for additional information on these transactions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Customers </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our five largest customers accounted for approximately 27% of our net revenues in 2008, 29% in 2007 and 28% in 2006. Our ten
largest customers accounted for approximately 36% of our net revenues in 2008, 40% in 2007 and 38% in 2006. One of our customers, Wal-Mart Stores,&nbsp;Inc., accounted for approximately 16% of our net revenues in 2008, 15% in 2007 and 14% in 2006.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Seasonality </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Demand for some of our products may be
influenced by holidays, changes in seasons or other annual events. However, sales of our products are generally evenly balanced throughout the year due to the offsetting nature of demands for our diversified product portfolio. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Competition </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We face competition in all aspects of our business.
Competitors include large national and international companies and numerous local and regional companies. Some competitors may have different profit objectives and some international competitors may be more or less susceptible to currency exchange
rates. We also compete with generic products and retailer brands, wholesalers and cooperatives. We compete primarily on the basis of product quality, brand recognition, brand loyalty, service, marketing, advertising and price. Moreover, improving
our market position or introducing a new product requires substantial advertising and promotional expenditures. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Distribution </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our products are generally sold to supermarket chains, wholesalers, supercenters, club stores, mass merchandisers, distributors, convenience stores, gasoline stations,
drug stores, value stores and other retail food outlets. In general, the retail trade for food products is consolidating. Food products are distributed through distribution centers, satellite warehouses, company-operated and public cold-storage
facilities, depots and other facilities. We currently distribute most products in North America through a combination of direct-store-delivery and warehouse delivery. Kraft International&#146;s products are distributed through warehouse delivery and
through the services of independent sales offices and agents. We support our selling efforts through three principal sets of activities: consumer advertising in broadcast, print, outdoor and on-line media; consumer incentives such as coupons and
contests; and trade promotions to support price features, displays and other merchandising of our products by our customers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">5 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Raw Materials </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We
are a major purchaser of dairy, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn products, soybean and vegetable oils, nuts, meat products, and sugar and other sweeteners. We also use significant quantities of plastic, glass and cardboard to package our products, and
natural gas for our factories and warehouses. We continuously monitor worldwide supply and cost trends of these commodities so we can act quickly to obtain ingredients and packaging needed for production. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We purchase our dairy raw material requirements, including milk and cheese, from independent third parties such as agricultural cooperatives and independent processors.
The prices for milk and other dairy product purchases are substantially influenced by market supply and demand, as well as by government programs. Dairy commodity costs on average were higher in 2008 than in 2007. Significant cost items in our
biscuit and grocery products are grains (wheat, corn and soybean oil). Grain costs have experienced significant increases as a result of burgeoning global demand for food, livestock feed and biofuels such as ethanol and biodiesel. Grain costs on
average were higher in 2008 than in 2007. The most significant cost item in coffee products is green coffee beans, which are purchased on world markets. Green coffee bean prices are affected by the quality and availability of supply, changes in the
value of the U.S. dollar in relation to certain other currencies and consumer demand for coffee products. Green coffee bean costs on average were higher in 2008 than in 2007. A significant cost item in chocolate confectionery products is cocoa,
which is purchased on world markets, and the price of which is affected by the quality and availability of supply and changes in the value of the British pound and the U.S. dollar relative to certain other currencies. Cocoa bean and cocoa butter
costs on average were higher in 2008 than in 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">During 2008, our aggregate commodity costs rose significantly as a result of higher dairy, coffee,
cocoa, wheat, nuts, meat products, soybean oil and packaging costs. For 2008, our commodity costs were approximately $1.8&nbsp;billion higher than 2007, following an increase of approximately $1.3&nbsp;billion for 2007 compared with 2006. Overall,
we expect commodity costs to moderately increase in 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The prices paid for raw materials and agricultural materials used in our products generally
reflect external factors such as weather conditions, commodity market fluctuations, currency fluctuations and the effects of governmental agricultural programs. Although the prices of the principal raw materials can be expected to fluctuate as a
result of these factors, we believe there will be an adequate supply of the raw materials we use and that they are generally available from numerous sources. We use hedging techniques to limit the impact of price fluctuations in our principal raw
materials. However, we do not fully hedge against changes in commodity prices, and these strategies may not protect us from increases in specific raw material costs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Intellectual Property </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We consider our trademarks, in the aggregate, to be&nbsp;material&nbsp;to our business. We
protect our trademarks by registration or otherwise in the U.S. and&nbsp;in&nbsp;other markets where we sell our products.&nbsp;Trademark protection continues in some countries for as long as the mark is used, and in other countries, for as long as
it is registered. Registrations generally are for renewable, fixed terms. From time to time, we&nbsp;grant&nbsp;third parties licenses to use one or more of&nbsp;our trademarks in particular locations.&nbsp;Similarly,&nbsp;we sell some of&nbsp;our
products under brands&nbsp;we license&nbsp;from third parties. These licensed brands include, among others: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Starbucks</I> coffee, <I>Seattle&#146;s Best</I> coffee and <I>Tazo</I> teas for sale in U.S. grocery stores and other distribution channels;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Starbucks </I>and <I>Seattle&#146;s Best</I> coffee T-Discs and <I>Tazo</I> teas T-Discs for use in our <I>Tassimo</I> hot beverage system;
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Capri Sun </I>packaged juice drinks for sale in the U.S., Canada and within our Developing Markets segment; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Taco Bell Home Originals</I> Mexican style food products for sale in U.S. grocery stores; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>California Pizza Kitchen</I> frozen pizzas for sale in grocery stores in the U.S. and Canada; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>South Beach Living </I>pizzas, meals, breakfast wraps, lunch wrap kits, crackers, cookies, snack bars, cereals and dressings for sale in grocery stores in the
U.S. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Additionally,&nbsp;we own&nbsp;numerous patents worldwide.&nbsp;While our patent portfolio is material to&nbsp;our
business,&nbsp;the loss of&nbsp;one patent or&nbsp;a&nbsp;group of related patents&nbsp;would not have a material adverse effect on our business.&nbsp;We have either been issued patents or have patent applications pending that relate to a number of
current and potential products, including products licensed to others. Patents, issued or applied for, cover inventions ranging from basic&nbsp;packaging techniques to processes relating to specific products and to the products themselves. Our
issued patents extend for varying periods according to the date of patent application filing or grant and the legal term of patents in the various countries where patent protection is obtained. The actual </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">6 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">protection afforded by a patent, which can vary from country to country, depends upon the type of patent, the scope of its coverage as determined by the
patent office or courts in the country, and the availability of legal remedies in the country. We consider that in the aggregate our patent applications, patents and licenses under patents owned by third parties are of material importance to our
operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We also have proprietary trade secrets, technology, know-how processes and&nbsp;related&nbsp;intellectual property rights that are not
registered. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Research and Development </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We pursue four
objectives in research and development: product safety and quality; growth through new products; superior consumer satisfaction; and reduced costs. We have approximately 2,400 food scientists, chemists and engineers working primarily in six key
technology centers: East Hanover, New Jersey; Glenview, Illinois; Tarrytown, New York; Banbury, United Kingdom; Paris, France; and Munich, Germany. These technology centers are equipped with pilot plants and state-of-the-art instruments. Research
and development expense was $499 million in 2008, $442 million in 2007 and $414&nbsp;million in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Regulation </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our U.S. food products and packaging materials are&nbsp;regulated by the&nbsp;Food and Drug Administration or, for products containing meat and poultry, the Food Safety
and Inspection Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.&nbsp;These agencies enact and enforce regulations relating to the manufacturing, distribution and labeling of food products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, various states regulate&nbsp;our U.S. operations by licensing plants, enforcing federal and state standards for selected food products, grading food products, inspecting plants and warehouses,
regulating&nbsp;trade practices&nbsp;related to the sale of dairy products and imposing their own labeling requirements on food products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Many of the food
commodities&nbsp;we use in&nbsp;our U.S. operations&nbsp;are subject to governmental agricultural programs. These programs have substantial effects on prices and supplies and are subject to Congressional and administrative review. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">All of&nbsp;our non-U.S. based&nbsp;operations are subject to local and national regulations,&nbsp;some of which are similar to those applicable to&nbsp;our U.S.
operations.&nbsp;For example, in the EU,&nbsp;requirements apply to labeling, packaging, food content, pricing, marketing and advertising and related areas. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Environmental Regulation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are subject to various federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to the protection of
the environment. We accrue for environmental remediation obligations on an undiscounted basis when amounts are probable and can be reasonably estimated. The accruals are adjusted as new information develops or circumstances change. Recoveries of
environmental remediation costs from third parties are recorded as assets when their receipt is deemed probable. In the U.S., the laws and regulations include the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and
Superfund, which imposes joint and severable liability on each responsible party. As of December&nbsp;31, 2008,&nbsp;our subsidiaries were involved in 67 active Superfund and other similar actions in the U.S. related to current operations and
certain former or divested operations for which we retain liability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Outside the U.S., we are subject to applicable multi-national, national and local
environmental laws and regulations in the countries in which we do business. We have specific programs across our international business units designed to meet applicable environmental compliance requirements. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on information currently available, we believe that the ultimate resolution of existing environmental remediation actions and our compliance in general with
environmental laws and regulations will not have a material effect on our financial results. However, we cannot quantify with certainty the potential impact of future compliance efforts and environmental remediation actions. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Employees </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2008, we employed approximately
98,000 people worldwide. Labor unions represent approximately 43% of our 39,000 U.S. employees. Most of the unionized workers at our domestic locations are represented under contracts with the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers
International Union; the United Food and Commercial Workers </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">7 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">International Union; and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. These contracts expire at various times throughout the next several years. Outside the
U.S., labor unions or workers&#146; councils represent approximately 72% of our 59,000 employees. Our business units are subject to various laws and regulations relating to their relationships with their employees. These laws and regulations are
specific to the location of each enterprise. In addition, in accordance with EU requirements, we have established a European Works Council composed of management and elected members of our workforce. We believe that our relationships with employees
and their representative organizations are good. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2008, we completed our five-year restructuring program (the &#147;Restructuring Program&#148;). In
connection with our severance initiatives, as of December&nbsp;31, 2008, we had eliminated approximately 15,200 positions, and we had announced our intent to eliminate an additional 3,800 positions. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Executive Officers of the Registrant </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The following were our
executive officers on February&nbsp;27, 2009: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Michael Osanloo</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">42</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President, Strategy</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Richard G. Searer</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">55</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President and President, Kraft North America</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Jean E. Spence</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">51</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President, Research, Development and Quality</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mary Beth West</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">46</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President&nbsp;and Chief Marketing Officer</FONT></P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld </I>was appointed as Chief Executive Officer of Kraft in June&nbsp;2006 and assumed the
additional role of Chairman in March 2007. Prior to that, she had been Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Frito-Lay, a division of PepsiCo, a food and beverage company. Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld had been employed continuously by Kraft in various
capacities from 1981 until 2003. Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is also a member of the Cornell University Board of Trustees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Brearton </I>was appointed
as Executive Vice President, Operations and Business Services effective January&nbsp;1, 2008. Prior to that, he served as Executive Vice President, Global Business Services and Strategy, as Senior Vice President of Business Process Simplification
and as Corporate Controller for Kraft. He previously served as a Senior Vice President, Finance for Kraft International. Mr.&nbsp;Brearton first joined Kraft in 1984. Mr.&nbsp;Brearton is also on the Board of Directors for Feeding America.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Clarke</I> joined Kraft as President, Kraft Europe on January&nbsp;2, 2009 and was appointed Executive Vice President and President, Kraft
Europe on January&nbsp;27, 2009. Prior to joining Kraft, Mr.&nbsp;Clarke spent 12 years with The Coca-Cola Company, a beverage company, most recently serving as President of the Northwest Europe and Nordics businesses from August 2005 to December
2008 and as President of the South Pacific and Korea businesses from March 2000 to July 2005. Mr.&nbsp;Clarke is also on the Advisory Board of the Inspire Foundation. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Firestone</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President, Corporate and Legal Affairs and General Counsel in January 2006. He previously served as Kraft&#146;s Executive Vice President, General Counsel and
Corporate Secretary. Prior to joining Kraft in 2003, Mr.&nbsp;Firestone served as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Philip Morris International, a tobacco company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Khosla</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President and President, Kraft International in January 2007. Before joining Kraft, he served as the Managing Director of the consumer and foodservice business
for the New Zealand-based Fonterra Co-operative Group, a dairy company. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Khosla spent 27 years with Unilever, a consumer products company, in India, London and Europe. Mr.&nbsp;Khosla also serves on the Board of Directors of Best
Buy Co., Inc. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;May </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President, Global Human Resources in October 2005. Prior to joining Kraft, she had been
Corporate Vice President, Human Resources for Baxter International Inc., a healthcare company, since February 2001. Ms.&nbsp;May also serves on the Board of Directors of MB Financial Inc. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">8 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;McLevish </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in October 2007. Prior to
that, he had been the Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Ingersoll-Rand Company Limited, an industrial company, since June 2002. Mr.&nbsp;McLevish also serves on the Board of Directors of Kennametal Inc. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Osanloo </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President, Strategy in April 2008.<I> </I>Prior to joining Kraft, Mr.&nbsp;Osanloo served as Senior Vice
President, Marketing at Harrah&#146;s Entertainment, a provider of branded casino entertainment, from July 2005 until March 2008. Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Osanloo was a partner in the retail and consumer products practice at Bain&nbsp;&amp; Company, a
management consulting firm, from August 1996 until June 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Searer</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President and President, Kraft North
America in September 2006.&nbsp;Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Searer served as the Group Vice President and President, North America Convenient Meals Sector. Mr.&nbsp;Searer joined Kraft in 1981. Mr.&nbsp;Searer also serves on the Board of Directors of Bush
Brothers&nbsp;&amp; Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;Spence</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President, Research, Development and Quality in January 2004. Prior to
her current position, Ms.&nbsp;Spence served as the Senior Vice President, Research and Development, Kraft North America. She joined Kraft in 1981. Ms.&nbsp;Spence also serves on the Board of Directors of International Life Sciences Institute.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;West </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer in October 2007. Previously, she served as a Group Vice
President for Kraft and President of the North America Beverages Sector. Ms.&nbsp;West joined Kraft in 1986. Ms.&nbsp;West also serves on the Board of Directors of J.C. Penney Co., Inc. and is a member of the Executive Leadership Council.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We adopted The Kraft Foods Code of Conduct for Compliance and Integrity, which qualifies as a code of ethics under Item&nbsp;406 of Regulation&nbsp;S-K.
The code applies to all of our employees, including our principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, and persons performing similar functions. Our code of ethics is available free of charge on
our website at <U>www.kraftfoodscompany.com</U> and will be provided free of charge to any shareholder submitting a written request to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. We will disclose any waiver
we grant to our principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller under our code of ethics, or certain amendments to the code of ethics, on our website at <U>www.kraftfoodscompany.com</U>.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, we adopted Corporate Governance Guidelines, charters for each of the Board&#146;s five standing committees and the Code of Business Conduct
and Ethics for Directors. All of these materials are available on our website at <U>www.kraftfoodscompany.com</U> and will be provided free of charge to any shareholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc.,
Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. Certain of these materials may also be found in the proxy statement relating to our 2009 Annual Meeting of Shareholders. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Available Information </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Internet address is <U>www.kraftfoodscompany.com</U>. Our Annual Reports on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on
Form&nbsp;10-Q, Current Reports on Form&nbsp;8-K and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, are available free of charge as soon as possible after we
electronically file them with, or furnish them to, the SEC. You can access our filings with the SEC by visiting <U>www.kraftfoodscompany.com</U>. The information on our website is not, and shall not be deemed to be, a part of this Annual Report on
Form 10-K or incorporated into any other filings we make with the SEC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">You can also read and copy any document that we file, including this Annual Report
on Form&nbsp;10-K, at the SEC&#146;s Public Reference Room at 100&nbsp;F&nbsp;Street, N.E., Washington, D.C. 20549. Call the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330 for information on the operation of the Public Reference Room. In addition, the SEC maintains an
Internet site at <U>www.sec.gov</U> that contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC. You can electronically access our SEC filings there. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">9 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1A.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Risk Factors. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>You should read the following risk factors
carefully in connection with evaluating our business and the forward-looking information contained in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. Any of the following risks could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, financial
condition and the actual outcome of matters as to which forward-looking statements are made in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. While we believe we have identified and discussed below the key risk factors affecting our business, there may be
additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our business, performance or financial condition in the future. </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We operate in a highly competitive industry, which may affect&nbsp;our profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The food industry is intensely competitive. We compete based on price, product innovation, product quality, brand recognition and loyalty, effectiveness of marketing, promotional activity and the ability to identify
and satisfy consumer preferences. From time to time,&nbsp;we may need to reduce&nbsp;our prices&nbsp;in response to&nbsp;competitive and customer pressures and to maintain&nbsp;our market share.&nbsp;Competition and customer pressures, however, also
may restrict&nbsp;our ability to increase prices in response to commodity and other input cost increases.&nbsp;Our results of operations will suffer if profit margins decrease, as a result of either a reduction in prices or increased input costs,
and&nbsp;if we are unable to increase sales volumes to offset those profit margin decreases. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We may also need to increase&nbsp;spending on marketing,
advertising and new product innovation to protect existing market share or capture increased market share. The success of&nbsp;our investments is&nbsp;subject to risks, including uncertainties about trade and consumer acceptance. As a
result,&nbsp;our increased expenditures may not maintain or enhance market share and could result in lower profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Our brands may be challenged
to compete against lower-priced private label products, particularly in times of economic downturns. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retailers are increasingly offering private label
products that compete with&nbsp;some of our products.&nbsp;Consumers&#146;&nbsp;willingness to purchase&nbsp;our products will depend upon&nbsp;our ability to offer products&nbsp;that appeal to consumers at the right price.&nbsp;It is also important
that our products provide higher value and / or quality to our customers than less expensive alternatives. If the difference in value or quality between our products and&nbsp;those of store brands narrows,&nbsp;or if such difference in quality is
perceived to have narrowed, then consumers may not&nbsp;buy&nbsp;our products. Furthermore,&nbsp;during periods of economic uncertainty, such as we are currently experiencing, consumers tend to purchase more private label or other economy brands,
which could&nbsp;reduce sales volumes of our&nbsp;higher margin products or&nbsp;there could be a shift in our&nbsp;product mix to&nbsp;our lower margin offerings.&nbsp;If we are not able to maintain or improve&nbsp;our brand image or value
proposition, it could&nbsp;have a material effect on our market share and&nbsp;our profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>The consolidation of retail customers, the loss of a
significant customer, or a material reduction in sales to a significant customer could&nbsp;affect our operating margins, our profitability, our sales and our results of operations. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retail customers, such as supermarkets, warehouse clubs and food distributors&nbsp;in&nbsp;the U.S., the EU and&nbsp;our other major markets, continue to consolidate. These consolidations have produced large,
sophisticated customers with increased buying power.&nbsp;These larger retailers, capable of operating with reduced inventories, can resist price increases and&nbsp;demand lower pricing, increased promotional programs and specifically tailored
products.&nbsp;They also may use shelf space currently used for&nbsp;our products for their own private label products. The consolidation of retail customers also increases the risk that a severe adverse impact on their business operations could
have a corresponding material adverse effect on us. Also,&nbsp;our retail customers may be affected by the current economic environment. For example, they may not have access to funds or financing and that could cause them to delay, decrease or
cancel purchases of our products, or to not pay us or to delay paying us for previous purchases. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">A few of our customers are material to our business and
operations. Our largest customer, Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., accounted for approximately 16% of our net revenues during 2008.&nbsp;During 2008, our five largest customers&nbsp;accounted for approximately 27% of our net revenues.&nbsp;There can be no
assurance that all significant customers will continue to purchase our products in the same quantities that they have in the past. The loss of any one of our significant&nbsp;customers or a material reduction in sales to a significant customer could
have a material adverse effect on our sales and results of operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Increased price volatility for commodities we purchase may affect our
profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are a major purchaser of&nbsp;commodities, including dairy, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn products, soybean and vegetable oils, nuts,
meat products, and sugar and other sweeteners. We also use significant quantities of plastic, glass and cardboard to package our products, and natural gas for our factories and warehouses.&nbsp;Price volatility for commodities&nbsp;we purchase has
increased due to conditions outside of&nbsp;our control, including the current economic environment, currency fluctuations, </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">10 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">availability of supply, weather, consumer demand and changes in governmental agricultural programs. Although we monitor our exposure to commodity prices as
an integral part of our overall risk management program, continued volatility in the prices of commodities we purchase could increase the costs of our products and services, and our&nbsp;profitability could suffer. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Our product sales depend on our ability to predict, identify and interpret changes in consumer preferences and demand, and our ability to develop&nbsp;and offer new
products rapidly enough to meet those changes. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Consumer preferences for food products&nbsp;change continually. For example, recently, consumers have
been increasingly focused on health and wellness with respect to the food products they buy. As a result,&nbsp;over the last several years our products have been subject to scrutiny relating to the health implications of obesity and trans-fatty
acids.&nbsp;Our success depends on&nbsp;our ability to predict, identify and interpret the tastes and dietary habits of consumers and to offer products that appeal to those preferences.&nbsp;We have been and will continue to be&nbsp;affected by
publicity concerning the health implications of&nbsp;our products,&nbsp;some of which could negatively influence consumer perception and acceptance of&nbsp;our products and marketing programs. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Furthermore, if&nbsp;we do not succeed in offering products that&nbsp;appeal to consumers, our sales and market share will decrease,&nbsp;and our profitability could
suffer. We must be able to distinguish among short-term fads, mid-term trends and long-term changes in consumer preferences. If&nbsp;we are unable to accurately predict which shifts in consumer preferences will be long-term, or&nbsp;if we fail to
introduce new and improved products to satisfy those preferences,&nbsp;our sales could decline. In addition,&nbsp;because of our varied consumer base, we must offer a sufficient array of products to satisfy the broad spectrum of consumer
preferences.&nbsp;If we fail to successfully expand our product offerings across a multitude of product categories or if we do not rapidly develop products in faster growing and more profitable categories,&nbsp;demand for our products will decrease
and our profitability could suffer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Our international operations are subject to additional risks. </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We generated approximately 49% of our 2008 sales, 43% of our 2007 sales and 40% of our 2006 sales in foreign countries.&nbsp;Our international operations are subject to
inherent risks, including fluctuations in currency values, unpredictability of foreign currency exchange controls, discriminatory fiscal policies, unexpected changes in&nbsp;local regulations and laws, and the uncertainty of enforcement of remedies
in&nbsp;foreign jurisdictions. In addition, foreign jurisdictions could impose tariffs, quotas, trade barriers, and other similar restrictions on our international sales.&nbsp;Moreover, our international business operations could be interrupted and
negatively affected by economic changes, terrorist activity, political unrest, and other economic or political uncertainties. All of these risks could result in increased costs or decreased revenues, either of which could adversely affect
our&nbsp;profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>If we are unable to expand our operations in certain emerging markets, our growth rate could be negatively affected.
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2007, we unveiled our strategies to grow our international operations with increased focus on four emerging markets: Brazil, Russia, China and other
regions of Southeast Asia. The success of our international operations depends in part on our ability to grow our business in these and other emerging markets. In some cases, emerging markets have greater political and economic volatility and
greater vulnerability to infrastructure and labor disruptions. In addition, emerging markets are becoming more competitive as other international companies grow globally and local, low cost manufacturers expand their production capacities. If we are
unable to increase our business in emerging markets, our market share and profitability could be adversely affected. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We may not be able to successfully
consummate proposed acquisitions or divestitures or successfully integrate acquired businesses. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">From time to time,&nbsp;we evaluate acquisition
candidates&nbsp;that would strategically fit&nbsp;our business objectives. If&nbsp;we are&nbsp;unable to complete, successfully integrate and develop these acquisition candidates&nbsp;to realize revenue&nbsp;growth and cost savings,&nbsp;our
financial results could be adversely affected. In addition, from time to time,&nbsp;we divest businesses that&nbsp;do not meet our&nbsp;strategic&nbsp;objectives, or do not meet&nbsp;our growth or profitability targets.&nbsp;Our&nbsp;profitability
may be&nbsp;affected by either gains or losses on the sales of, or lost operating income from those businesses.&nbsp;Also, we&nbsp;may not be able to complete desired or proposed divestitures on&nbsp;terms favorable to us.&nbsp;Moreover, we
may&nbsp;incur asset impairment charges related to acquisitions or divestitures which may reduce&nbsp;our profitability.&nbsp;Finally, our acquisition or divestiture activities may&nbsp;present financial, managerial and operational risks, including
diversion of management attention from existing core businesses, difficulties integrating or separating personnel and financial and other systems, adverse effects on existing business relationships with suppliers and customers, inaccurate estimates
of fair value made in the accounting for acquisitions and amortization of acquired intangible assets which would reduce future reported earnings, potential loss of customers or key employees of acquired businesses, and indemnities and potential
disputes with the buyers or sellers.&nbsp;Any of these activities could affect our product sales, financial conditions and results of operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">11 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Business process improvement initiatives to simplify and harmonize our business processes may fail to operate as
designed and intended. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We regularly implement business process improvement initiatives to simplify and harmonize our systems processes and to optimize
our performance. Our current business process initiatives include, but are not limited to, the Kraft Europe Reorganization, the delivery of an SAP enterprise resource planning application, and the outsourcing of certain administrative functions. If
our business process improvement initiatives fail, our ability to improve existing operations and support future growth could be delayed. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Product
recalls, injuries caused by products or other legal claims could affect our sales, reputation and profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling products for human consumption
involves inherent legal risks.&nbsp;We could be required to recall products due to product contamination, spoilage or other adulteration, product misbranding or product tampering.&nbsp;We may also suffer losses if our&nbsp;products or operations
violate applicable laws or regulations, or&nbsp;if our products cause injury, illness or death. In addition,&nbsp;our advertising could be the target of claims of false or deceptive advertising.&nbsp;A significant product liability or other legal
judgment against&nbsp;us, or a widespread product recall may&nbsp;adversely affect our profitability.&nbsp;Moreover, even if a product liability or consumer fraud claim is unsuccessful, has no merit or is not pursued, the negative publicity
surrounding&nbsp;assertions&nbsp;against our products or processes could adversely affect our&nbsp;reputation and profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We operate in a highly
regulated environment. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Food production and marketing are highly regulated by a variety of federal, state, local and foreign agencies. New regulations
and changes to existing regulations are issued regularly. Increased governmental regulation of the food industry, such as proposed requirements designed to enhance food safety or to regulate imported ingredients, could&nbsp;increase our costs and
adversely affect&nbsp;our profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>The effects of the present economic environment on the credit markets and changes in our credit ratings could
adversely affect our liquidity. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our $4.5 billion revolving credit facility supports our commercial paper issuances. We use our commercial paper
program, in addition to international credit lines, for daily funding requirements. The present economic environment, in general, has restricted access to the credit markets. If the present economic environment worsens, our access to commercial
paper, our ability to refinance our credit facility by the time it expires in April 2010 and our ability to secure additional long or short-term financing, on terms and within a time period acceptable to us, could negatively affect our liquidity. In
addition, a downgrade in our credit ratings would likely reduce the amount of commercial paper we could issue, and it could&nbsp;raise our&nbsp;borrowing costs for both short-term and long-term debt offerings. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Volatility in the equity markets or interest rates could substantially increase our pension costs and have a negative impact on our operating results and
profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the end of 2008, the projected benefit obligation&nbsp;of our defined benefit pension plans was $9.3&nbsp;billion and&nbsp;assets
were $7.0&nbsp;billion. The difference between plan obligations and assets, or the funded status of the plans,&nbsp;significantly affects the net periodic benefit costs of&nbsp;our pension plans and the ongoing funding requirements of those plans.
Among other factors, changes in interest rates, mortality rates, early retirement rates, investment returns and the market value of plan assets can (i)&nbsp;affect the level of plan funding; (ii)&nbsp;cause volatility in the net periodic pension
cost; and (iii)&nbsp;increase&nbsp;our future funding requirements. In addition,&nbsp;if we divest certain businesses, we may be required to increase future&nbsp;contributions to the benefit plans and the related net periodic pension cost could
increase. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We expect to make approximately $390 million in contributions to our pension plans in 2009, which is approximately $170 million more than we
made in 2008. We also expect that our net pension cost will increase by approximately $200 million to approximately $440 million in 2009. The current economic environment increases the risk that we may be required to make additional cash
contributions to the pension plans and recognize further increases in our net pension cost beyond 2009. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Item&nbsp;1B.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Unresolved Staff Comments. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have received no written comments
regarding our quarterly, annual or current reports from the staff of the SEC that remain unresolved. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">12 </FONT></P>

worldwide. In North America, we have 58 facilities, and outside of North America, we have 110 facilities located in 45 countries. These manufacturing and processing facilities are located throughout the following territories: </FONT></P> <P
